content.question:
Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Students run an experiment to determine resistance and capacitance. The students construct the circuit shown with battery <math alttext="E m f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, resistors <math alttext="R 1"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="R 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, capacitor <math alttext="C"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and switches <math alttext="S 1"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="S 3"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Voltmeter <math alttext="V"><mrow><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></math> and ammeter <math alttext="A"><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></math> are attached in the positions shown to measure the voltage and current. Initially, all the switches are open and the capacitor holds zero charge. Switches <math alttext="S 1"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and <math alttext="S 3"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> are then closed while switch <math alttext="S 2"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> is open.

(a) Sketch the graphs of voltage as a function of time and current as a function of time as measured by the meters from the time immediately after the switches are closed until the time <math alttext="t sub 0"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> when the capacitor is fully charged.

frqParts.text:
Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Students run an experiment to determine resistance and capacitance. The students construct the circuit shown with battery <math alttext="E m f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, resistors <math alttext="R 1"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="R 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, capacitor <math alttext="C"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and switches <math alttext="S 1"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="S 3"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Voltmeter <math alttext="V"><mrow><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></math> and ammeter <math alttext="A"><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></math> are attached in the positions shown to measure the voltage and current. Initially, all the switches are open and the capacitor holds zero charge. Switches <math alttext="S 1"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and <math alttext="S 3"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> are then closed while switch <math alttext="S 2"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> is open.

(a) Sketch the graphs of voltage as a function of time and current as a function of time as measured by the meters from the time immediately after the switches are closed until the time <math alttext="t sub 0"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> when the capacitor is fully charged.

After the capacitor is fully charged, switch <math alttext="S 1"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is opened and switch <math alttext="S 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is closed simultaneously.

(b) Sketch the graphs of voltage as a function of time and current as a function of time as measured by the meters from the time immediately after switch <math alttext="S 1"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is opened and switch <math alttext="S 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is closed until the time <math alttext="t sub 0"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> when the capacitor is fully discharged.

In a second experiment the switches and the capacitor are removed and the resistor near the battery moved to replace the capacitor, as shown above. The resistors have the same resistance. A variable voltage source is applied and the measurements from the voltmeter and ammeter were recorded. The data are shown in the chart below.

Voltage <math alttext="volts"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>V</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="14 point 5"><mstyle><mrow><mn>14.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="12"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="8 point 5"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="5"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="2 point 5"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

Current <math alttext="amps"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>A</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="7"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="5 point 7 5"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.75</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="4 point 5"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="2 point 5"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="1 point 2"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

(c) Plot the experimental data of the voltage as a function of the current on the graph below. Clearly scale and label all axes, including units if appropriate. Draw a straight line that best represents the data.
(d) Using your graph, determine a value for one of the resistors.

One of the resistors is a thick wire of cross sectional area A and length L which has a resistivity which varies along its length according to the equation <math alttext="rho equals, rho naught times, open parenthesis, 1 minus alpha times x squared, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ρ</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>ρ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>o</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>α</mi><msup><mrow><mtext>x</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> where <math alttext="rho naught"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ρ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>o</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="alpha"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are constants.

(e) Derive an expression for the resistance of the wire.

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
